rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:23
rsbNotes.text: 15:23 brook Kidron. A valley running from north to south along the eastern side of Jerusalem and separating Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:24
rsbNotes.text:
15:24 Abiathar . . . Zadok. See note 8:17.

ark of the covenant of God. See notes 1 Sam. 3:3; 4:3.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:25
rsbNotes.text: 15:25 Carry the ark of God back. David clearly resists any magical understanding of the ark’s power (contrast the elders of Israel, 1 Sam. 4:3). Rather, he casts himself on the Lord’s mercy.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:26
rsbNotes.text: 15:26 let him do to me what seems good to him. David humbly accepts the Lord’s will (10:12 note; 1 Sam. 3:18), yet this does not prevent him from taking steps to secure his survival (vv. 28, 32–36).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:27
rsbNotes.text: 15:27 Go back to the city. Zadok, Abiathar, and their sons will prove useful to David’s cause in 17:15–21.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:28
rsbNotes.text: 15:28 fords of the wilderness. Probably the region along the western shore of the Dead Sea; see 17:16.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:30
rsbNotes.text:
15:30 Mount of Olives. See note on v. 23.

barefoot . . . head covered. These are signs of grief and sorrow (Esth. 6:12; Is. 20:2–4; Jer. 14:3, 4; Mic. 1:8).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:32
rsbNotes.text:
15:32 Hushai. No sooner does David pray that Ahithophel’s counsel be confounded than he is presented, in the person of Hushai, with the means of accomplishing his objective.

the Archite. The Archites were of Canaanite descent (Gen. 10:15-17) and their territory was west of Bethel (Josh. 16:2).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 15:37
rsbNotes.text: 15:37 Hushai, David’s friend. Probably an official counselor. See 1 Chr. 27:33.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:1
rsbNotes.text: 16:1 Mephibosheth. See note 4:4.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:4
rsbNotes.text: 16:4 all that belonged to Mephibosheth is now yours. While David appears to believe Ziba’s tale of Mephibosheth’s treachery, he will change his ruling after hearing Mephibosheth’s side of the story (19:24–30).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:5
rsbNotes.text:
16:5 Bahurim. See note 3:16.

Shimei. As a kinsman of Saul, Shimei may have held David responsible for the deaths of Abner and Ish-bosheth (vv. 7, 8; on David’s innocence, see 3:21, 26, 28; 4:9, 12 and notes). He may also have resented David’s permitting seven of Saul’s descendants to be executed by the Gibeonites (21:1 note). As a resident of Bahurim, moreover, Shimei may have been upset by David’s treatment of Michal, Saul’s daughter, for it was there that her second husband was ordered to cease following her as she was being taken back to David (3:16).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:8
rsbNotes.text: 16:8 The Lord has avenged on you. Shimei is correct that divine retribution plays a part in David’s distress, but it is not because of any injustice to the house of Saul. It was the result of David’s sin against Uriah and Bathsheba (12:11).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:9
rsbNotes.text:
16:9 Abishai the son of Zeruiah. See note 2:18.

dead dog. See note 1 Sam. 24:14.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:11
rsbNotes.text: 16:11 let him curse. David refuses to silence Shimei for several reasons. The Lord has prompted him to curse (v. 10); if his own son wants to kill him, how much more a kinsman of Saul; if the cursing is unjust, the Lord may repay David with good (v. 12). David’s ready submission to God’s judgment is consistent with his character (12:20–23; 15:26) and reminiscent of Eli (1 Sam. 3:18 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:15
rsbNotes.text: 16:15 Ahithophel. See note 11:3 (“Eliam”).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:16
rsbNotes.text: 16:16 Hushai the Archite. See note 15:32.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:17–19
rsbNotes.text: 16:17–19 Absalom’s suspicion of David’s “friend” (v. 16; 15:37) elicits from him a clever reply that he will be loyal to the one whom the Lord and all Israel have chosen. Moreover, it is a natural thing for one who served a father to serve his son also.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:21
rsbNotes.text: 16:21 Go in to your father’s concubines. To remove any thought among Absalom’s followers of a reconciliation with David, Ahithophel counsels Absalom to lie with David’s concubines who had been left behind (15:16). This would make clear Absalom’s desire for the throne (3:7 note; 12:8 note; 1 Kin. 2:22). Whatever the motivation, such behavior was detestable to God (Lev. 18).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Sam 16:22
rsbNotes.text: 16:22 Absalom went in. This action fulfills the judgment announced by Nathan in 12:11, 12.
